item.title: Adam Toledo: Chicago police release video of officer shooting boy
item.description: Bodycam footage shows an officer shouting "Drop it" before shooting Adam Toledo once in the chest.

item.title: Who is going to Prince Philip's funeral?
item.description: Covid restrictions mean only 30 mourners will be allowed to attend the funeral of the duke.

item.title: Matt Hancock and sister own shares in NHS contract firm
item.description: The health secretary is accused of "cronyism" but the government says he acted "entirely properly".

item.title: Covid-19: Scotland eases restrictions and summer holiday season 'can be saved'
item.description: Five things you need to know about the coronavirus pandemic this Friday morning.

item.title: Indianapolis mass shooting: Eight dead at FedEx facility
item.description: Many people are injured as a gunman opens fire at a FedEx facility before taking his own life.

item.title: Scotland eases rules on travel and meeting up
item.description: The Scottish government says the lockdown changes are designed to help reunite families and close friends.

item.title: China's economy grows 18.3% in post-Covid comeback
item.description: The record figures for the first quarter of the year are skewed due to last year's nationwide lockdown

item.title: TUI says summer holiday season can be saved
item.description: The boss of Europe's biggest holiday company thinks successful vaccine programmes can prevent another washout.

item.title: US imposes sanctions on Russia over cyber-attacks
item.description: Dozens of entities are targeted over attacks including alleged interference in the 2020 elections.

item.title: Families need cannabis prescriptions support, say MPs and peers
item.description: Politicians complain that only three NHS scripts have been issued since the law changed in 2018.

item.title: Colin the Caterpillar cake row: Judge Rinder gives his verdict
item.description: Marks & Spencer has begun legal action against Aldi, arguing the retailer's Cuthbert the Caterpillar cake infringes its Colin the Caterpillar trademark.

item.title: Newspaper headlines: 'Brothers apart' amid Queen's 'final tribute'
item.description: The Duke of Edinburgh's funeral plans - and the choreography of the procession - make the front pages.

item.title: Escaping the anti-vax conspiracy rabbit hole
item.description: Catherine was a big believer in anti-vaccine conspiracy theories, but has since stopped believing in them.

item.title: Cages around houses: Life at Belfast's peace wall
item.description: There are over 20 miles of peace walls - or peace lines - across Northern Ireland.

item.title: Scottish election: How independence could be key to how people vote
item.description: The BBCâ€™s Connor Gillies takes a look at how the upcoming elections in Scotland could affect the likelihood of an indyref2.

item.title: Line of Duty: Who is the Ted Hastings of Westminster?
item.description: The Line of Duty references have been flying thick and fast as MPs argue over the lobbying row.

item.title: Rebuilding Notre-Dame cathedral... with 1,000 oak trees
item.description: Two years since the fire, workers are preparing for the reconstruction phase of the Paris landmark.

item.title: Chile sees Covid surge despite vaccination success
item.description: The country's vaccination rollout is one of the fastest in the world, so why are Covid cases surging?

item.title: How sex surrogates are helping injured Israeli soldiers
item.description: Therapy with surrogate sexual partners is used in Israel to rehabilitate badly injured soldiers.

item.title: Health anxiety: The fear of illness making people quit jobs and move home
item.description: For some people, Covid has fuelled a debilitating mental health condition known as health anxiety.

item.title: How George Floyd's death changed a small Iowa town
item.description: Issues of race were rarely discussed in Decorah, until a death 160 miles away changed everything.

item.title: Lateral-flow tests: What are the risks and benefits?
item.description: What are the risks and benefits from using wide-scale lateral-flow tests?

item.title: Smaller and better smartphone cameras are on the way
item.description: Smaller and more powerful lenses promise to bring even better smartphone cameras.

item.title: Rampant Arsenal win in Prague to set up semi-final against Emery's Villarreal
item.description: Arsenal impressively sweep aside Slavia Prague to reach the Europa League semi-finals with a fine away victory in the second leg.

item.title: Man Utd to face Roma in Europa League final four after beating Granada
item.description: Edinson Cavani scores the winner as Manchester United set up a Europa League semi-final against Roma with a comfortable 4-0 aggregate win over Granada.

item.title: I need fans at World Championship to bring out best in me - Trump
item.description: World number one Judd Trump says the return of fans will help bring out his best at the World Snooker Championship in Sheffield.

item.title: 'I'm delighted to get that time' - Renshaw sets new British record at Olympic trials
item.description: Molly Renshaw looks set for a place at Tokyo 2020 after winning gold and setting a new British record in the 200m breaststroke at the Olympic trials.

item.title: Classic battles with Vettel still surpass new Verstappen rivalry - Hamilton
item.description: Lewis Hamilton says his battle with Max Verstappen for this year's drivers' title does not yet live up to his rivalry with Sebastian Vettel.

item.title: 'I'd come home crying because all these tough players kicked lumps out of me'
item.description: As he prepares for Sunday's FA Cup semi-final against Leicester, Southampton winger Nathan Redmond tells BBC Sport about the role his mother has played in his career.

item.title: Prince Philip: Duke's four children to walk alongside coffin at funeral
item.description: The names of the 30 guests who will be at Saturday's funeral service are released by Buckingham Palace.

item.title: Why was Prince Philip born on this dining table?
item.description: A lesser known fact about the Duke of Edinburgh is he was born on a dining table in Corfu. But why?

item.title: Prince Philip funeral: What are the plans and timings?
item.description: What time is the funeral for the Duke of Edinburgh and what will happen?

item.title: Prince Philip: How deaths of public figures can impact others
item.description: Many were affected by the death of the duke but why do people grieve over those they have never met?

item.title: Prince Philip: Military takes part in rehearsals for funeral
item.description: Prince Philip will be remembered in a service at St George's Chapel, at Windsor Castle, on Saturday.

item.title: Prince Philip: How can Prince Harry attend the funeral?
item.description: The Duke of Sussex has returned to the UK for the first time since "stepping back" from royal duties.

item.title: Obituary: HRH The Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh
item.description: Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, won widespread respect for his steadfast and constant support of the Queen.

item.title: Prince Philip: A simple, family farewell
item.description: A no-nonsense moderniser, the duke's last service to the monarchy may be in the way he departs it, reports the BBC's Jonny Dymond.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid: What's happening with universities as lockdown eases?
item.description: Face-to-face courses cannot resume on campuses in England until at least 17 May.

item.title: Covid: How does the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine work?
item.description: People under 30 are being offered an alternative to the AstraZeneca vaccine after a review into rare blood clots.

item.title: Covid: When can I go on holiday abroad or in the UK?
item.description: A traffic light system ranking foreign countries by coronavirus risk is to be introduced - the rules on UK holidays are also easing.

item.title: Covid: How do I get a lateral flow or PCR test?
item.description: Everyone in England is being encouraged to take two rapid coronavirus tests a week.

item.title: Prince Philip: A turbulent childhood stalked by exile, mental illness and death
item.description: In marrying, Philip was able to regain the "simple pleasures" of family life he had lost aged eight.

item.title: Race report: Was controversy part of the plan?
item.description: How the government handled the release of a contentious report on racial disparity in the UK.

item.title: 'We found a baby on the subway - now he's our son'
item.description: Danny Stewart saw something on the floor of an NY subway station - soon he would treasure it more than anything.

item.title: Letterbox contact: â€˜Donâ€™t my birth children have a right to know Iâ€™m dying?'
item.description: Diagnosed with a terminal illness, Hanna wanted to tell the twins taken from her at 16 - but had no way of reaching them.
